oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Barge Canal near Falls Road Bridge, 1917
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

The view is to the north from the Falls Road Bridge. The section pictured was one of the most difficult to dig. Large quantities of dynamite were needed to blast through the solid rock. In the left foreground, a machine moves along railroad tracks laid in the cut. In the right background, a steam shovel works near a bridge.

Published in "Rochester Herald 1910-07-03" (1910-07-03)

overall: 5 x 7 in.

Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. Barge Canal

Installing the big crane at Barge Canal. The two operators' cages are suspended from the traveling cranes on the harbor side of the new warehouse. The Court Street Dam is under construction as part of the New York State Barge Canal Terminal in Rochester, N.Y. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Barge Canal Harbor Dam with ice,1922 - 3
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Court Street Dam Forms Safe Harbor for Barge Canal Terminal

Chunks of ice clog the gates of the Court Street Dam. The Genesee River water is high and turbulent. The newspaper article states that the photograph was made just before the gates were raised for the winter. "The ice had formed to such a thickness on the gates that the powerful machinery could not move the sectors. Men had to descend to the lower face of the dam and chop away the ice before the gates could be moved. The night following the raising of the gates, the flood water from up the valley reached the city and passed through the open dam safely".

Published in "Rochester Herald 1922-01-11" (1922-01-11)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Court Street Dam in full operation, 1922
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Court Street Dam Forms Safe Harbor for Barge Canal Terminal

The Court Street Dam is in full operation. Water spurts through the gates as well as over the spillway. The river level is low and tree limbs lie on the exposed shale of the riverbed. The words "N. Y. State Canal Harbor" are mounted on the superstructure of the dam.

Published in "Rochester Herald 1922-06-24" (1922-06-24)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Canal Inspection boat at Court Street Dam, 1920
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Court Street Dam Forms Safe Harbor for Barge Canal Terminal

The newspaper article describes this scene as the "[Canal] Inspector's boat lying near the dock at the power house which operates the big dam at Rochester's Barge Canal Harbor." The stone arches of the Court Street Bridge can be seen in the right background. The pointed spire and clock faces of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Station, on the east side of the river, can be seen in the center background behind the two men who stand on the catwalk.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Court Street Dam in full operation, 1920 - 4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Court Street Dam Forms Safe Harbor for Barge Canal Terminal

A man demonstrates one of the two "power trolleys" which are used to lift sections of the dam. The trolleys move from one end of the dam to the other, as needed, using electricity to power a windlass-and-chain arrangement that does the actual lifting of the gates. This is a side view of the trolley.

Weigh Lock

The weighlock (or weigh lock) was built in 1852. It is located on the east side of the Genesee River, just south of Court Street. Canal boats enter the covered area, where the toll is determined by the weight of the loaded boat.

It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Barge Canal Crosses the Genesee River at Water Level

Two men fill holes with dynamite in preparation for blasting during construction on the Barge Canal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Excavation for the new subway,1921-1922
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
From Canal to Subway
When the Erie canal was re-routed south and west of the city of Rochester, the original canal excavation was deepened and widened to accommodate a subway and Interurban trolleys.

Workmen excavate the bed of the new subway. Steam shovels work at the left bank of the worksite. One man uses a shovel on a pile of small stones. Another stacks wooden panels. A bicycle leans on a storage chest. Coils of wire, stone rubble, and pieces of lumber litter the foreground.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cofferdam nears completion near Elmwood Avenue, 1917
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Cofferdam

This cofferdam above the Elmwood Avenue Bridge in Genesee Valley Park will allow workmen to descend into the bed of the river, where they will excavate for the foundation of a temporary, movable dam. This temporary dam is to serve until the completion of the permanent, concrete dam above Court Street, allowing the opening of navigation on the Barge Canal through Genesee Valley Park. The Durand boathouse can be seen in the background.

Published in "Rochester Democrat & Chronicle 1933-12-24" (1933-12-24)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cofferdam breaks, 1928
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Cofferdam

Rushing flood waters break the cofferdam in the Genesee River. The water flowing through the breach carried the wooden sides of the cofferdam downstream, causing the loss of $1,000 worth of timber, but the sill of the movable dam stayed safely in the riverbed. The Elmwood Avenue Bridge can be seen in the upper right corner of the photograph.

Published in "Rochester Herald 1918-02-16" (1918-02-16)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Erie Canal causes damage near Bushnell's Basin, 1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Bushnell's Basin Canal Break

The outer layer of the back of a house has been torn off by the force of escaping Erie Canal water. The wall, complete with its windows, shutters, and clapboard siding, is wedged between two trees and the rest of the structure. The end of the house, visible at right, shows damaged and missing siding. A man's coat hangs from a protruding nail. More trees can be seen in the background. The house is owned by R. M. Newcombe and occupied by Ernest Daly [neither man is pictured].

oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Barge Canal
By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Bushnell's Basin Canal Break

Escaping Erie Canal water has seriously damaged the front of a house. The left half has gaping doorways and most of the siding is missing. The right half has been completely torn away. The end of the house, visible at right, shows an intact upper story while the lower part is missing. The house is owned by R. M. Newcombe and occupied by Ernest Daly[neither man is pictured].

By the early 20th century the original Erie Canal, which went through the center of Rochester, proved to be too narrow and too shallow for commercial service. It was closed, "dewatered", and transformed into a subway. Commercial traffic was diverted south around the city on the Barge canal to cross the Genesee River. These changes were part of a redesign of the old canal, renaming it the Barge Canal, thus emphasizing the commercial aspect.

Bushnell's Basin Canal Break

Men driving piles into the sand for the foundation of a flume and reinforcements over the culvert at Bushnell's Basin. This is a replacement for the temporary flume built shortly after the break in the canal in October, 1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Part of the West Avenue Bridge falls into the canal bed, 1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
From Canal to Subway
When the Erie canal was re-routed south and west of the city of Rochester, the original canal excavation was deepened and widened to accommodate a subway and Interurban trolleys.

Part of the West Avenue Bridge is photographed as it falls into the canal bed. It falls into a section that will become part of the subway.

Published in "Rochester Herald 1922-10-11" (1922-10-11)
